children.name: meal
children.definition: an occasion when you eat food, for example breakfast or dinner, or the food that you eat on that occasion:
examples: We must have a meal together some time.
Dinner is the main meal of the day for most people.
a simple meala simple meal of soup and bread
COMMON ERRORS
►Do not say'take a meal'. Sayhave a meal.

children.name: have a meal
children.definition: eat a meal
examples: We usually have our evening meal fairly early.

children.name: eat a meal
examples: When they had eaten their meal, they went out for a walk.

children.name: cook/make a meal
children.definition: alsoprepare a mealformal
examples: Who cooks most of the meals?

children.name: serve a meal
examples: The bar serves snacks and meals.

children.name: fix a mealinformal especially American English
children.definition: make a meal

children.name: go
children.definition: out
examples: for a mealHow about going out for a meal tonight?

children.name: take sb
children.definition: out
examples: for a mealHe took Anna out for a meal and then to the theatre.

children.name: an evening/midday meal
examples: The evening meal is served at 7.30.

children.name: the main meal
examples: They had their main meal at lunch time.

children.name: a three-course/five-course etc meal
children.definition: a meal with several separate parts
examples: a three-course meal, including appetizer and dessert

children.name: a good meal
children.definition: a meal that is large enough and tastes good
examples: We’ll get a good meal there.

children.name: a decent meal/a square meal
children.definition: alsoa proper mealBritish English
examples: (= with enough good food to satisfy you )I hadn’t had a decent meal in days.

children.name: a big/large meal
examples: We don’t have a big meal at lunchtime, usually just sandwiches.

children.name: a hot meal
examples: With a hot meal inside me, I began to feel better.

children.name: a delicious meal‘
examples: It was a delicious meal,’ Merrill said politely.

children.name: a heavy meal
children.definition: with a lot of rich food
examples: A heavy meal is likely to make you feel sleepy.

children.name: a light meal
children.definition: with not a lot of food
examples: a light meal of salad

children.name: a balanced meal
children.definition: with some of each type of food, to keep you healthy
examples: We make healthy, balanced meals for our children.

children.name: a gourmet meal
children.definition: one with very nice and often complicated food
examples: The day ended with a gourmet meal in a good restaurant.

children.name: a slap-up mealBritish English informal
children.definition: a good meal
examples: Jennie cooked us a slap-up meal.

children.name: a full meal
children.definition: a complete meal
examples: I’m not hungry enough to eat a full meal.

children.name: a healthy meal
examples: Healthy meals can still be quick and easy to prepare.

children.name: a school meal
children.definition: provided by a school
examples: Many of the children are receiving free school meals.

children.name: regular meals
children.definition: ones that are eaten at the same time each day
examples: Patients are advised to eat regular meals.

children.name: sth to eat
children.definition: especiallyspokena meal, especially asmallorquickmeal:
examples: Can I get you something to eat?

children.name: have sth to eat
examples: We’ll have something to eat, and then go out.
You should have something to eat before you go out.
I’m not hungry -- I had something to eat earlier.
Do you want me to fix you something to eat?

children.name: feeding
children.definition: feedUK/US  a meal, consisting only of milk, that a baby has: bữa ăn (trẻ)
examples: A young baby needs small feeds at frequent intervals.
Lois has gotten tired of the late night feedings.

children.name: have a feedBritish
examples: Her baby has its lunchtime feed, then goes to sleep.
The baby had a feed an hour ago, so she can't be hungry.

children.name: breakfast
children.definition: the meal you have in the morning:
examples: Wehadbacon and eggsfor breakfast.

children.name: have/eat breakfast
examples: Paul got up, washed and had breakfast.

children.name: have something for breakfast
examples: What do you usually have for breakfast?

children.name: a big breakfast
examples: Most people don’t eat a big breakfast nowadays.

children.name: a good/proper breakfast
children.definition: big and healthy
examples: I think kids need a good breakfast before they go to school.

children.name: a hearty breakfastwritten
children.definition: big
examples: The price includes a hearty breakfast.

children.name: a small/ light breakfast
examples: She ate a light breakfast of toast and coffee.

children.name: an English/a full breakfast
children.definition: a big breakfast with bacon, egg, toast etc - used especially in hotels
examples: A lot of people like to have an English breakfast on holiday.

children.name: a cooked/fried breakfast
children.definition: bacon, egg, toast etc
examples: Do you feel like having a cooked breakfast?

children.name: a buffet breakfast
children.definition: one in a hotel, where you serve yourself
examples: A buffet breakfast is served in the hotel's elegant dining room.

children.name: a continental breakfast
children.definition: coffee and bread with butter and jam
examples: Continental breakfast can be served in your room.

children.name: a quick/hasty/hurried breakfast
examples: I grabbed a quick breakfast and ran to the bus stop.

children.name: a long/leisurely breakfast
children.definition: not hurried
examples: On Sunday mornings I like to have a leisurely breakfast.

children.name: an early/late breakfast
examples: We had an early breakfast and left before 7.30.

children.name: a working breakfast
children.definition: at which you talk about business
examples: She suggested we meet at 8.30 for a working breakfast.

children.name: the breakfast dishes
examples: Did you put the breakfast dishes in the dishwasher?

children.name: the breakfast things
children.definition: dishes, packets etc
examples: Dad was clearing the breakfast things away.

children.name: a breakfast table/room
examples: The house has a large kitchen and a breakfast room.

children.name: breakfast cereal
examples: Many breakfast cereals are high in sugar.

children.name: breakfast time
examples: I don’t like talking at breakfast time.

children.name: breakfast television/TV
children.definition: programmes on television in the early morning
examples: The children all eat their cereal in front of breakfast television.

children.name: brunch
children.definition: especially US a meal eaten late in the morning, as a combination of breakfast and lunch: bữa nửa buổi
examples: On the first day of the vacation we all slept late, then had a huge brunch.
They served smoked salmon, cream cheese and bagels for brunch.

children.name: a meal in the middle of the day
lunch
children.definition: a meal eaten in the middle of the day:
examples: What’s for lunch?
I've just had lunch with John.

children.name: have lunch
examples: Have you had lunch?

children.name: eat lunch
examples: What time do you usually eat lunch?

children.name: have something for lunch
examples: I usually have sandwiches for lunch.

children.name: take sb
children.definition: out
examples: to lunch(= pay for someone else's lunch when you go to a restaurant )He took her out for lunch at a local pub.

children.name: go out for/to lunch
children.definition: have lunch at a restaurant
examples: I don't often go out to lunch, as it's expensive.

children.name: come for/to lunch
children.definition: come to someone's house for lunch
examples: Can you come to lunch tomorrow?

children.name: break for lunch
children.definition: stop doing something in order to eat lunch
examples: Why don't we break for lunch about 1 o'clock?

children.name: make lunch
examples: You clear the table while I make lunch.

children.name: a light lunch
children.definition: a small lunch
examples: After a light lunch, he would take a nap each afternoon.

children.name: a packed lunchBritish English,a bag/sack lunchAmerican English
children.definition: food such as sandwiches that you take to school etc
examples: Most of the children had brought packed lunches.

children.name: a business/working lunch
children.definition: a lunch during which you also do business
examples: She was having a business lunch with a customer.

children.name: a school lunch
children.definition: a lunch provided by a school
examples: Free school lunches are provided for the poorest children.

children.name: Sunday lunchBritish English
children.definition: a hot lunch eaten on Sunday
examples: Mum always cooks a chicken for Sunday lunch.

children.name: a lunch break
children.definition: a time when you stop working to eat lunch
examples: We took a half hour lunch break.

children.name: the lunch hour
children.definition: the time when people stop working to eat lunch
examples: I try to go out for a walk during my lunch hour.

children.name: a lunch date
children.definition: when you meet someone for lunch
examples: I've got a lunch date.

children.name: at lunch
examples: I’m afraid he’s at lunch until two.

children.name: over lunch
examples: A dozen senators met over lunch with the Chinese ambassador.

children.name: dinner
children.definition: especially UK the meal eaten in the middle of the day. This word is also used for large meals eaten in the middle of the day on Sundays or holidays.
examples: He comes home for his dinner, then goes back to the factory.

children.name: school dinnersUK(= meals provided at school in the middle of the day )
examples: School dinners are served in the canteen.

children.name: Sunday/Christmas/Thanksgiving dinner(= a special meal eaten on Sunday etc )
examples: We usually have a walk after Christmas dinner.

children.name: noon meal
children.definition: midday mealUK/ US  the meal eaten in the middle of the day - use this especially when describing what happens in other countries:
examples: In Spain, the midday meal almost always starts with tomato salad.
The noon meal was carried out to the fields where the harvesters were working.

children.name: dinner
children.definition: the main meal of the day, eaten in the evening:
examples: What time do you usually have dinner?
We’re having fish for dinner tonight.
What's for dinner?

children.name: have/eat dinner
examples: Why don't you come and have dinner with us?

children.name: make/cook dinner
examples: I offered to cook dinner.

children.name: have sth for dinner
examples: I thought we might have pasta for dinner tonight.

children.name: have sb for/to dinner
examples: We're having a few friends round to dinner.

children.name: ask/invite sb to dinner
examples: Let's ask Kate and Mike to dinner.

children.name: come for/to dinner
examples: Mark is coming over for dinner.

children.name: go out for/to dinner
children.definition: go and eat in a restaurant
examples: Would you like to go out for dinner on Saturday?

children.name: serve dinner
children.definition: start giving people food
examples: Dinner is served between 7 and 11 pm in the hotel restaurant.

children.name: a three-course/four-course etc dinner
examples: The cost of the hotel includes a three-course dinner.

children.name: a romantic dinner
children.definition: for two people in a romantic relationship
examples: Clive and Denise were enjoying a romantic dinner for two in a quiet French restaurant.

children.name: a candle-lit dinner
children.definition: with only candles for lighting
examples: Chris treated his girlfriend to a candle-lit dinner.

children.name: a leisurely dinner
children.definition: not hurried
examples: I enjoy having a leisurely dinner with some friends at the weekend.

children.name: a black-tie dinner
children.definition: where people wear special formal clothes
examples: He was invited to a black-tie dinner at one of the Oxford colleges.

children.name: a slap-up dinnerBritish English informal
children.definition: with a lot of good food
examples: Mum always makes a slap-up dinner for me when I go home.

children.name: TV dinners
children.definition: meals that you eat while watching TV
examples: TV dinners in aluminium containers can be found in the freezer departments of many supermarkets.

children.name: a dinner party
children.definition: when someone's friends are invited for a special evening meal
examples: We are having a dinner party on Saturday.

children.name: a dinner guest
examples: The dinner guests began arriving at about seven o'clock.

children.name: supper
children.definition: especially UK the meal you eat in the evening: bữa tối
examples: After supper we watched a video.
Would you like to come to supper tonight?

children.name: eat/have (your) supper
examples: I had my supper and went to bed.

children.name: tea
children.definition: UK a meal you eat at home early in the evening: bữa chiền muộn
examples: What’s for tea?

children.name: have (your) tea
examples: The children came home from school, had tea and did their homework.

children.name: evening meal
children.definition: the meal eaten in the evening:
examples: After the evening meal they sat around the cooking-fire and talked.
Preparing the evening meal can take up to three hours.

children.name: picnic
children.definition: a cold meal that you take to a park or the countryside to eat outside: bữa ăn ngoài trời
examples: We took a picnic down to the beach.
We decided tohaveapicnicdown by the lake.
►Do not say ‘do a picnic’ or ‘make a picnic’. Sayhave a picnic.

children.name: have a picnic
examples: They were having a picnic on the beach.

children.name: go on/go for a picnic
examples: If it's fine, we'll go for a picnic.

children.name: a picnic area/site
children.definition: a special area with tables where people can have picnics
examples: There is a picnic area next to the car park.

children.name: a picnic spot/place
children.definition: a place that is suitable for a picnic
examples: We found a beautiful picnic spot.

children.name: a picnic basket/hamper
children.definition: a container in which you carry food for a picnic

children.name: barbecue
children.definition: (written abbBBQ)a party when you cook and eat food outside: tiệc ngoài trời
examples: I’ll get some burgers and ribs for the barbecue.

children.name: have a barbecue
examples: If the weather’s nice we’ll have a barbecue.

children.name: al fresco
children.definition: if you eatal fresco, you have a meal outdoors: ngoài trời
examples: Guests can dine al fresco on a terrace with stunning views of the valley below.
I’d enjoy al fresco eating much more if it wasn’t for all the wasps!

children.name: course
children.definition: one of the parts of a meal that are served one after the other:

children.name: three-course/five-course etc meal
examples: The ticket includes entry and a four-course meal.

children.name: first/second/main etc course
examples: We had fish for the main course.
The waiter brought the first course, a simple leek and potato soup.

children.name: appetizer
children.definition: starterUK /US  the first part of a meal in a restaurant: món khai vị
examples: What would you like for a starter - soup or garlic mushrooms?

children.name: a delightful appetizer of small clams
examples: We had soupas a starter, followed by steak.

children.name: dessert
children.definition: /puddingUK  the sweet part of a meal that you have at the end: món tráng miệng
examples: ‘Would you like a dessert, Madam?’ ‘Yes please, I’ll have the cheesecake.’
have sth for dessert/ pudding
I had fruit salad for dessert.
At children’s parties, it’s traditional to have jelly and ice-cream for pudding.

children.name: for afters
children.definition: UK spoken if you have sthfor afters, you have it as your dessert:
examples: We’re having roast beef, with apple pie for afters.
For afters, it’s rice pudding.
What'sforafters, Dad?

children.name: dish
children.definition: a particular kind of food cooked in a particular way and served at a meal: món ăn
examples: My favourite Italian dish is lasagne.
In addition to the extensive Tandoori menu, there is a wide selection of vegetarian dishes.
This soup is substantial enough to serve as amain dish(= the biggest part of a meal ).

children.name: main course
children.definition: / entrée the biggest course in a meal,entréeis used especially on restaurant menus: món chính
examples: For the main course we had cheese and onion pie.
The menu includes a few hot entrées.
For the main course we had roast turkey with vegetables.

children.name: side dish
children.definition: food eaten with the main course, such as vegetables: I’ll have the salad as a side dish:món kèm theo (rau)

children.name: snack
children.definition: a small amount of food that is eaten between main meals or instead of a meal: bữa nhẹ
examples: Just before bedtime he had a snack of bread and cheese.
The children have mid-morning snacks at about 11 o'clock -- usually fruit and a drink.
Drinks andlight snacksare served at the bar.

children.name: light
children.definition: a light meal, lunch, etc is one in which you do not eat much food, especially food that contains a lot of fat, so that it does not make your stomach feel too full: nhẹ
examples: She prepared a light lunch of salad and cheese.
You can have a light meal four hours before the game but only have drinks after that.

children.name: bite
children.definition: a very small meal that you eat quickly:
examples: We’ll have a bite then go into town.

children.name: a bite to eat
examples: There’s just time for a quick bite to eat before the film begins.

children.name: refreshments
children.definition: small amounts of food and drink that are provided for people at a party, meeting etc:
examples: The children walked around at the party offering refreshments.
Meetings are open to the public, and refreshments are provided.

children.name: light refreshments
examples: Catering tents provide coffee, snacks, and other light refreshments.

children.name: dinner party
children.definition: dinner part a formal meal in your home when you invite friends or guests: tiệc liên hoan (tại nhà)
examples: He is a charming man, the kind of person you would want to sit next to at a dinner party.

children.name: have a dinner party
examples: We’re having a dinner party on Tuesday. Would you like to come?
I'mhaving/ givinga dinner party next week.

children.name: dinner
children.definition: a formal evening meal for a large number of people, especially in a public place such as a hotel:
examples: She had a ticket for a dinner and fashion show at the Castle Hotel.
Ann and I attended a dinner at the City Chamber of Commerce.

children.name: banquet
children.definition: a special formal meal with a lot of very good food and a large number of people, especially important people, which usually takes place on a special public occasion: yến tiệc; yến hội; tiệc lớn; tiệc trọng thể
examples: A huge banquet was planned to celebrate the city’s millennium.

children.name: a state banquet hosted by the French Prime Minister
examples: Medieval banquets are held in the castle once a month.

children.name: luncheon
children.definition: a formal meal in the middle of the day for a large number of people, especially in a public place such as a hotel: bữa tiệc trưa
examples: Over 200 attended the Women in Journalism luncheon last Tuesday.

children.name: a meal you buy in a restaurant and eat at home
takeout
children.definition: takeawayUK B1 /USB1 a meal that you buy from a restaurant and then eat at home: thức ăn mang về
examples: Let’s have a takeaway tonight.

children.name: Dave just lives on beer and takeaways
examples: I don’t feel like cooking tonight -- can we get some takeout?

children.name: a takeout pizza
examples: The phone rang just as the Kunkels started eating their Chinese takeout.

children.name: to go
children.definition: to take awayB1UK /US  food or drink totake awayorto gois intended to be taken away from the restaurant where you have bought it so that you can eat it somewhere else:
examples: Joe ordered a slice of pizza and a Coke to go.
Do you want that hamburger to eat here or to take away?
I'd like a cheeseburger and strawberry milk shake to go, please.

children.name: three-course meal
children.definition: a large meal with three separate parts, of the type that is usually served in restaurants:
examples: I can’t eat a three-course meal at lunch time -- it’s just too much.
You can get a three-course meal for $25 in the barbecue grill.

children.name: feast
children.definition: a very large meal for a large number of people, to celebrate a special occasion: yến tiệc
examples: The Christmas celebrations in Fiji are rounded off by a huge feast on Christmas Day.

children.name: have a feast
examples: We decided to have a feast to celebrate the victory.

children.name: give a feast
examples: He gave a feast to which all the villagers were invited.

children.name: hold a feast
children.definition: arrange for a feast to take place
examples: The feast was held in the college dining hall.

children.name: prepare a feast
examples: A catering company was hired to prepare the feast.

children.name: a great feast
children.definition: a large and impressive feast
examples: A great feast took place at the palace.

children.name: a wedding/marriage feast
examples: This dish is traditionally served at wedding feasts.

children.name: heavy
children.definition: aheavymeal, lunch, dinner etc is one in which you eat a lot of food, and that makes you feel tired and your stomach feel full:
examples: You shouldn’t eat a heavy meal before going swimming.
After a heavy lunch my father fell asleep almost immediately.

children.name: slap-up meal
children.definition: UKinformala large meal with a lot of good food: bảnh, chiến, không sợ tốn kém
examples: If they give me the job I’ll take you out for a slap-up meal.

children.name: spread
children.definition: a large meal for several people: bữa tiệc linh đình
examples: They were looking forward to the spread that Judith had prepared.
Sheila laid on (= made)a lovely spread for us.

children.name: a meal in which you choose and serve your own food
buffet
children.definition: a meal in which food is put on a table and you serve yourself from the things that are there:
examples: We’re not having a big formal meal at the wedding - just a buffet
Try out all-you-can-eat buffet - only £5 per person
buffet breakfast/lunch/supper
The price includes morning coffee, buffet lunch, and afternoon tea.

children.name: finger food
children.definition: noun thứcăndùng tay đểăn
examples: food that you can eat without using knives, forks or spoons

children.name: sit-down
children.definition: sit-down meal/dinner etca meal etc in which everyone in a group, usually a large group, sits at tables: (bữa ăn) ngồi
examples: We usually organize a sit-down dinner, but we wanted to go for something less formal thisyear.
We offer a cafeteria and a sit-down service at very reasonable rates.

children.name: packed lunch
children.definition: nounUK (USbox lunch,Australiancut lunch)bữa ăn mang theo
examples: a light meal put in a container, usually to take with you somewhere to be eaten later
box lunchnoun[ C ] (alsobag lunch)
US forpacked lunch
